name: Village Weaver
description: The male is predominantly yellow, with dark markings on the back, a black head, and a rusty nape. The female is gray-brown.
image_alt: Village Weaver, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
reproduction: Females lay 3–4 eggs, incubating them for 17 days.
attractions: It also visits plantations and gardens. It gathers in numerous colonies, communicating with loud calls. The male builds a rough spherical nest, adding a 3–10 cm entrance tunnel during incubation as effective protection against predators, especially reptiles and small carnivores. Nest-building is the male’s task, while the female evaluates it. If satisfied, she lines the nesting chamber and begins laying eggs.
